fm.rrh: Spin dependence of the fundamental plane
fm.ti: Spin dependence of the fundamental plane of black hole activityQ.1Q.2Q.3

affg.aff: CEICO, Institute of Physics of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Na Slovance 1999/2, 182 21 Prague, CzechiaQ.4
Department of Astronomy, Harvard University, 60 Garden St., Cambridge, MA 02138, USA

absg.p: he Fundamental Plane (FP) of Black Hole (BH) Activity in galactic nclei relates X-ray and radio luminosities to BH mass and accretion rate. However, there is a large scatter exhibited by the data, which motivated us for a new variable. We add BH spin as a new variable and estimate the spin dependence of the jet power and disk luminosity in terms of radio and X-ray luminosities. We assume the Blandford-Znajek process as the main source of the outflow, and find that the jet power depends on BH spin stronger than quadratically at moderate and large spin values. We perform a statistical analysis for 10 AGNs which have sub-Eddington accretion rates and whose spin values are measured independently via the reflection or continuum-fitting methods, and find that the spin-dependent relation describes the data significantly better. This analysis, if supported with more data, could imply not only the spin dependence of the FP relation, but also the Blandford-Znajek process in AGN jets.Q.6

sect1.p: Although nearly every galaxy contains a supermassive Black Hole (SMBH) at its core (Kormendy & Ho 2013), the Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs) are a small portion of this large SMBH family, and jet producing BHs are a tenth of all AGNs (Begelman, Blandford & Rees 1980; Kellermann et al. 1989). Such systems have been shown to be described by an approximate power law relation between BH mass, X-ray and radio luminosity, called Fundamental Plane (FP) of black hole activity (Merloni, Heinz & Di Matteo 2003; Falcke, Koerding & Markoff 2004; Koerding, Falcke & Corbel 2006; Gultekin et al. 2009; Kording, Fender & Migliari 2006). For BHs with outflow and an accretion disk, it is usually considered that X-ray luminosity is often linked with the accretion power (though it also gets contribution from the jet power) and radio luminosity is considered as an indicator of jet power. Hence, the FP relation can equivalently be expressed in terms of BH mass, disk luminosity and jet power. The jet and disk connection in such BH systems result in the mutual scaling of the radio and X-ray (or optical) luminosities (Heinz & Sunyaev 2003; Merloni et al. 2003; Falk et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006; Gultekin et al. 2009; Kording et al. 2006; Plotkin et al. 2012; Saikia, K’ording & Falcke 2015).

The Fundamental Plane relation typically applies for radiatively inefficient AGNs with sub-Eddington accretion rates. However, AGN data shows large scatters relative to the FP relation. Since BH spin is expected to have an important role in both emitted radiation and jets (McClintock, Narayan & Steiner 2014) and expectedly the functional dependencies of the jet and disk power on the spin are different, we suggest that the deviations from the FP solution may result from the BH spin. Therefore, by adding BH spin as a new variable, we predict that the data lies approximately on this new 4-variable relation. In this context, we study the spin dependence of the jet and accretion power and translate the results to the FP quantities, radio and X-ray powers.

On top of the angular frequency and size of the BH horizon, BH spin controls the location of the inner layers of the accreting matter, which affects the released energy fraction per mass as radiation. Moreover, as inner layers of accreting matter comes closer to the horizon, the magnetic field around the black hole gets stronger. We assumed Blandford-Znajek (BZ) process (Blandford & Znajek 1977) (see also (Blandford, Meier & Readhead 2019) for a recent review) as the source of the jet luminosity, Ljet, and it predicts the jet power scales quadratically with BH spin for small values of the spin. Our estimation confirms this scaling and we further find that jet power has a stronger functional dependence on spin at higher values.

We use independent spin measurements from two well-established methods, namely the X-ray reflection and continuum fitting, to test our prediction (Vasudevan et al. 2016; Reynolds 2019). We found that the spin modified FP describes data remarkably better, reducing the χ2 error per degree of freedom from ∼12.27 to ∼2.56 for 10 AGNs. This result could possibly be improved further by taking into account the variation of the accretion disk thickness and the nonlinearities between Ljet − LR and Ldisk − LX. This result, if supported with more data, could imply the existence of the BZ in AGN jets on top of the spin dependence of the FP relation.

sect1.ti: THE NEED FOR A NEW VARIABLE IN FP
sect1.p: Fundamental Plane variables (BH mass, radio and X-ray luminosities) are derived from two main variables : mass and accretion rate. However, the 3 AGNs in the Table , 3C 120, IRAS 00521-7054 and MRK 79, show that these two variables are not enough to explain the data. Namely, these 3 AGNs have masses of around 107.75M⊙ and X-ray power of around implying these BHs have nearly same M and , but their radio luminosities are different by more than 3 orders of magnitude. Therefore, it is difficult to explain this variation in the radio spectrum for AGNs by only mass and accretion rate. This fact motivates us to suggest spin as an additional missing variable (this point was also discussed in Ref. (Merloni et al. 2003) and recently in (Daly 2016)).4

sect1.ti: BH SPIN DEPENDENCE OF DISK LUMINOSITY AND JET POWER
sect1.p: Theoretical results and general relativistic magnetohydrodynamical (GRMHD) simulations, have demonstrated that the spin energy can be a dominant portion of the jet power (Tchekhovskoy, McKinney & Narayan 2012; Tchekhovskoy, Narayan & McKinney 2010; McKinney 2005; McClintock et al. 2014). This is supported by observations indicating jet power that is orders of magnitude1-4 larger than the accretion power (e.g. (McClintock et al. 2014)). Here we focus on the Blandford-Znajek process which is based on energy extraction from a Kerr BH in the presence of magnetic field set by accretion disk (Blandford & Znajek 1977). We assume other processes will be sudominant such as wide-angle winds or the Blandford-Payne process (Blandford & Payne 1982) (recent simulation results show that winds in low accretion rate systems carry a small portion of the outflowing energy (Almeida & Nemmen 2020), while BP may still have some important role (Moscibrodzka, Falcke & Noble 2016)).1-4

We start by expressing jet luminosity, Ljet and bolometric disk luminosity,1 Ldisk in terms of three physical parameters : i) BH mass, MBH (or equivalently, the Eddington luminosity LEdd), ii) dimensionless accretion rate, , and iii) the dimensionless BH spin, , with J being the angular momentum of the BH,11

where and are the spin dependent functions for the jet power and disk luminosity, respectively. Dimensional arguments set θ = β = 1. As shown in the next section, the matter inflow to the BH and electric current around the BH are interconnected (setting the external magnetic field around BH), and the jet power is related with the inflowing energy density, which sets γ = 1. Finally, κ is set depending on the accretion state.There are three main regimes for the κ parameter : i) in the extremely low accretion rates () , ii) for mildly accreting system () κ ≃ 2, and iii) for large inflow rates () κ ≃ 1.1
sect1.sect2:
Spin Dependence of the Disk Luminosity
The spin dependent term, , shows the radiation conversion efficiency of the accreting matter into BH. The energy released as radiation is some fraction of the difference in the energy of the accreting matter at large radius and at innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO). This radiation efficiency increases as the spin of the BH increases because the innermost stable orbit comes closer to the event horizon. Radiation efficiency can be expressed by using circular equatorial geodesic equation as (see (Bardeen, Press & Teukolsky 1972)).
where . This formula produces familiar results such as and . sadsd

sect2.ti: Spin Dependence of the Jet Power
sect2.p: Although, isolated BHs are characterized by their mass, electric charge (expectedly small) and spin, numerous astrophysical phenomena can be observed around them in the presence of accretion disk. We assume Blandford-Znajek (BZ) process is the dominant source of the jet power .2 This process can be interpreted as the radiative energy outflow from a material with finite resistance moving in external magnetic field. Assume a piece of material with finite resistance rotates in the magnetic field, the electromotive force induced by this rotating body is , where is its angular frequency, B is the external magnetic field, and R is its characteristic size. A similar expression has been derived in BZ formalism as (Blandford & Znajek 1977; McKinney & Gammie 2004)

where Sr indicates the radial energy flow (T0r component), Ai indicates the electromagnetic vector potential, comma is a partial derivative with respect to given coordinate, ΩA is the angular frequency of the field lines, ΩH is the angular frequency of the horizon (defined below) and with Σ = r2 + a2cos 2θ.

In order to extract energy out, the field line angular frequency should be less than horizon angular frequency, ΩA < ΩH. Assuming the field line velocity is approximately the Keplerian values at regions before the plunging, one can evaluate . This implies that for , , no energy extraction is expected and this value approximately sets the threshold for jet production. For moderate and large spin values, the field line frequency is found approximately as half of the horizon frequency, ΩA ≃ ΩH/2, as in Ref (Blandford & Znajek 1977).

One can define the magnetic field strength as so that the pressure and energy density resulting from magnetic field can be expressed as ∝ B2 (without metric modifications on the indices). Given the above relations, the jet luminosity can be expressed as
where is an expectedly number which can be also modified by the polar dependence of the magnetic field, , and is the dimensionless angular frequency of the horizon. Note that .

The system is assumed to be axisymmetric (azimuthal) and stationary. In Ref. (Balbus & Hawley 1991), it is shown that the weak magnetic fields develop a strong MHD instability (and further numerically studied in (Hawley, Gammie & Balbus 1995)), saturating the field strength near equipartition values (Goodman & Xu 1994). Hence we have,

with β representing a factor , μ is the mass of the individual particle, L is the angular momentum per particle (conserved quantity for geodesics at Kerr background), n is the number density of particles, γ is Lorentz factor.

We employ the continuity equation via the conservation of the particle number density, Jν = n · uν, which can be expressed as . Due to stationarity and axisymmetry, partial derivatives of time and azimuthal angle vanish. We also assume that number density is a variable averaged over polar angle. We end up with,
where . We estimate the scaled specific angular momentum using the geodesic expression at the equator as (Bardeen et al. 1972)

where upper/lower signs are for prograde/retrograde orbits. Note that at large large distances, (r/GM) ≫ 1, we have which is the standard Keplerian result. Using eqn (6),we estimate the strength of the magnetic field in the innermost layers of the disk as

Next we consider the magnetic field near the horizon, BH, by assuming that the plunging region, the region between ISCO and event horizon, satisfies nearly vacuum properties. The layers of charged particles near the ISCO form a current loop threading the horizon. The standard dipole magnitude for a loop is

where I is the current magnitude and Aloop is the area of the region the current circulates. One can integrate over various rings that contribute to magnetic dipole moment around the horizon, however since the number density of the disk drops rapidly, the ISCO gives the dominant contribution to the magnetic field around horizon which allows us to represent the disk as a loop for this part of the calculation.
The radiation pressure is assumed to be comparable with the magnetic force exerted on the disk. This gives yielding

Typically the radial velocity is expressed as r ≃ Kepler · f(α, ϵ), where f is a coefficient set by gas specific heat ratio, ϵ, and viscosity parameter, α, described in Shakura-Sunyaev prescription (Shakura & Sunyaev 1973, 1976). We neglect the potential spin dependence of f. In the last s, we evaluate the expression near the ISCO,
where ∓ indicating the prograde/retrograde rotation respectively, with and (Bardeen et al. 1972). is a monotonically decreasing function of spin. We have () and ().

It is important to note that similar results can be obtained following the arguments in Ref. (Heinz & Sunyaev 2003) which indicate that the dynamically cooled systems have a magnetic field dependence in the form as . Furthermore, detailed numerical simulations confirm approximately the radial dependence of the magnetic field estimated above (Hirose et al. 2004). Our jet power expression becomes

This result shows an interesting behaviour at large values of BH spin. For fixed M and , jet power depends on the amplitude of the angular frequency. At small spin values, , is nearly constant, hence . For moderate spin values, we have , which is valid in the regime , and finally, , for , in the large spin regime. All these regimes are approximately fitted as dashed lines to the exact relation given in Fig. , where in lower horizontal axis with a maximum value of amax = 0.998, and H in the upper horizontal axis with a maximum value of H, max ≃ 0.939. It is remarkable that for geometrically thick and fast spinning BHs, similar results were found in detailed simulations (Tchekhovskoy et al. 2010).

sect1.ti: EVIDENCE FOR SPIN MODIFICATION OF THE AGN FUNDAMENTAL PLANE
sect1.p: The Fundamental Plane of black hole activity is a scaling expression for outflowing BHs with sub-Eddington accretion rates relating the BH mass, X-ray and radio luminosities (Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006; Gultekin et al. 2009). This relation implies a coupling between the jet and the disk power, frequently dubbed as jet-disk symbiosis (Falcke & Biermann 1995; Falcke, Malkan & Biermann 1995) since X-rays gives a measure of accretion power, and radio emission a measure of jet power. Remarkably, FP expression has been shown to extend from masses of order solar mass up to supermassive BHs, which might be considered as an indication of the universality of jet production. In a radiatively inefficient systems with α being a number in the range 2-3, close to 2.3 (Narayan & Yi 1994, 1995; Abramowicz et al. 1995) and (Blandford & Konigl 1979). Hence, the Fundamental Plane equation is expressed as (Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006)
where luminosities are in units of erg · s−1 and the mass of BH in solar masses, M⊙.

This result assumes that LX and LR are only functions of M and . However for moderate and large spin values, both luminosities also strongly depend on the BH spin. On general grounds, the LR − Ljet relation is quantified as (Merloni & Heinz 2007; Cavagnolo et al. 2010). A similar relationship exists between the X-ray power and the bolometric disk luminosity, LX ∝ Ldisk. Since both accretion power and jet power have different spin dependencies, this fact results in many orders of magnitude deviations between data and the standard FP relation.

We aim to remove these strong discrepancies by incorporating BH spin into the Fundamental Plane. For that purpose, we express our findings for the jet power (equation 13) and disk luminosity (equation 2) in terms of FP variables, LX and LR. Finally, we test our predictions for 10 AGNs, given in Table 0, whose spin values are measured independently and which are all in sub-Eddington regime. We label these relations as SMFP, the abbreviation of, ‘Spin Modified Fundamental Plane’.
The SMFP relation can be expressed as
Introducing the scalings LR, 38 = (LR/1038erg · s−1), LX, 40 = (LX/1040erg · s−1), and MBH, 8 = (MBH/108M⊙), one can express all the data in the form

Superscript (i) is the label of each AGN. In standard Fundamental Plane relation, spin is set to a constant value and spin information is not included. Δ quantifies the scatter of each data point with respect to the FP predictions as the variance of all the data points is minimized. Hence, by definiton, ΔFP = 0 for the standard FP relation (Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006). However, Δ changes between −3 to 2 for various data points.

When BH spin is included, Δ becomes a function of the BH spin. In Fig. , we show that the data fits this new prediction better by studying the suppression of the scatter. In order to show that the inclusion of the spin information decreases considerably the amount of scatter, we invert the equation above and define the scatter function as
In the SMFP, this function is predicted as

We obtain , after minimizing the error variance. We also find that the AGNs nearly on the standard FP prediction corresponds to .3Fig. shows the data points for the 10 AGNs given in Table 0 as green dots. The blue dots and corresponding error bars are produced by employing the spin measurements and measurement errors in equation (18). It is clearly seen that in almost all cases, the spin modified expression tracks the data points better than the spin-blind standard prediction.

sect1.ti: ANALYSIS WITH BH SPIN IN THE FUNDAMENTAL PLANE
sect1.p: We employ the data given in Table, and compute two quantities that signify the importance of the spin dependence. First, we use the (face value of the) independently measured spin values and calculate standard deviation for Δ in both FP and Spin Modified FP (SMFP). Second, we compute χ2 error per degree of freedom, by taking into account the experimental error in spin measurements via using a top-hat probability distribution function for each spin value within a 1-σ error range. In both cases, N = 10 for our analysis.

where ‘#pts’ indicate the number of sample points. As discussed in the previous section, Δth = 0 for FP , and for Spin Modified FP, it is given in equation. We obtain and . It should be noted that for AGNs with spin information, the variance is also consistent with the larger samples used in Refs (Merloni et al. 2003; Koerding et al. 2006) .4

We suggest that the nonlinear effects of spin modification on the radiation efficiency and jet power is the main cause of this behaviour and our SMFP prediction shows a remarkable consistency with the data. Note that the selection of data might have a role at some degree and an analysis with higher precision spin and radiation data could allow us to test our predictions better.
We calculate χ2 parameter per degree of freedom as

Here , and , and due to top hat distribution estimation. Nearly all measurements have mass, radio and X-ray measurements with an error of 0.2 in log base, so we set ΔLR = ΔLX = ΔM = 0.2. We obtain and . Hence the inclusion of spin correction improves the fitting considerably .5

We define and plot in Fig. , this new spin modified variable, (on the bottom panel) and LR (on the left panel) as a function of . In both cases the slope of the line is 1. For the standard FP plane, there is considerable scatter (shown in the top panel), but the scatter decreases considerably with this new variable. However, the prediction curve on the right panel is still not razor-thin. There are potentially some reasons for that including the thickness of the accretion disk enters as an independent variable, data uncertainties, LX − Ldisk and LR − Ljet connection, etc and they are discussed in more detail in the next subsections.

sect2.ti: Spin Dependence of the Fundamental Plane
sect2.p: As discussed in the previous section, there exists a natural cutoff value for the spin value in the Blandford-Znajek(BZ) process, . In the regime of low spins, winds and Blandford-Payne type processes dominate over BZ. This leads to a nearly constant and small outflow for small spins. However, we estimate that BZ quickly starts dominating the power outflow at moderate spin values and the jet power grows even more nonlinearly for large spins. At low spin values, the ISCO is nearly constant and the angular frequency grows quadratically. As the spin grows the location of the inner layers of the accretion disk (equivalently the location of the source for the magnetic field) gets closer to the horizon. As a result, the BZ output changes more dramatically with growing spin. Since the jet and radiation 6 efficiency have different functional dependence on the spin value, this results in strong scatter of the data from the standard FP relation when the spin information is not included , and .

If one assumes only quadratic dependence to spin value, the jet power grows from to about a factor of 6, and interestingly, the radiation efficiency also grows by a factor of 62013 from small spin values to large spin values, This can be easily seen either from equation(2) or approximately from the variation of the location of the ISCO in inverse gravitational potential, . Transfering these results to the FP variables, we get that the spin dependent contribution to the X-ray and radio power is modest. When we repeat our statistical analysis for the Ljet ∝ a2, we find only slight improvement in deviations, namely and . However, the stronger spin dependence of the jet power results in and .
Here we note some potential reasons about the residual scatter in SMFP:

sect1.p: In accreting and outflowing BHs, the Fundamental (Abramowicz et al. 1995; Akiyama et al. 2019; Almeida & Nemmen 2020)Plane relation is one of the most important scalings relating three variables: the radio luminosity (indicating jet power), X-ray luminosity(indicating bolometric disk luminosity) and the BH mass. Although standard FP equation gives a good description of jet producing systems with sub-Eddington accretion rate, there are still considerable deviations around this relation. In order to explain these deviations, we investigated the spin dependence of the jet power and accretion power. We can summarize the effects of the BH spin on the jet and accretion power as follows: As the spin grows i) a larger fraction of the gravitational energy can be released as radiation since the inner orbits of the accreting matter could come closer to the horizon, ii) the magnetic field amplitude around the horizon grows since the source for the magnetic field comes closer, iii) the angular frequency of the horizon grows, iv) the size of the horizon decreases.
We derived three main results:

This result could possibly be improved further by taking into account the variation of the accretion disk thickness and the nonlinearities between Ljet ΓêÆ LR and Ldisk ΓêÆ LX. All these regimes are approximately fitted as dashed lines to the exact relation given in Fig. , where in lower horizontal axis with a maximum value of amax = 0.998, and H in the upper horizontal axis with a maximum value of H, max Γëâ 0.939. It is remarkable that for geometrically thick and fast spinning BHs, similar results were found in detailed simulations Tchekhovskoy et al. 2010. Table to be deletesdasasda1asdssdeEVIDENCE FOR SPIN MODIFICATION OF THE AGN FUNDAMENTAL PLANE The Fundamental Plane of black hole activity is a scaling expression for outflowing BHs with sub-Eddington accretion rates relating the BH mass, X-ray and radio luminosities Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006; Gultekin et al. 2009 Falcke et al. 2004; Gultekin et al. 2009; Koerding et al. 2006;Merloni et al. 2003. This relation implies a coupling between the jet and the disk power, frequently dubbed as jet-disk symbiosis Falcke & Biermann 1995; Falcke, Malkan & Biermann 1995 since X-rays gives a measure of accretion power, and radio emission a measure of jet power. Remarkably, FP expression has been shown to extend from masses of order solar mass up to supermassive BHs, which might be considered as an indication of the universality of jet production. In a radiatively inefficient systems with ╬▒ being a number in the range 2-3, close to 2.3 Narayan & Yi 1994, 1995; Abramowicz et al. 1995 Abramowicz et al. 1995;Narayan & Yi 1994, 1995 and Blandford & Konigl 1979. Hence, the Fundamental Plane equation is expressed as Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006 Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006;Merloni et al. 2003 Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006;Merloni et al. 2003 where luminosities are in units of erg ┬╖ sΓêÆ1 and the mass of BH in solar masses, MΓèÖ. This result assumes that LX and LR are only functions of M and . However for moderate and large spin values, both luminosities also strongly depend on the BH spin. On general grounds, the LR ΓêÆ Ljet relation is quantified as Merloni & Heinz 2007; Cavagnolo et al. 2010 Cavagnolo et al. 2010;Merloni & Heinz 2007. A similar relationship exists between the X-ray power and the bolometric disk luminosity, LX Γê¥ Ldisk. Since both accretion power and jet power have different spin dependencies, this fact results in many orders of magnitude deviations between data and the standard FP relation. We aim to remove these strong discrepancies by incorporating BH spin into the Fundamental Plane. For that purpose, we express our findings for the jet power equation 13 and disk luminosity equation 2 in terms of FP variables, LX and LR. Finally, we test our predictions for 10 AGNs, given in Table 1, whose spin values are measured independently and which are all in sub-Eddington regime. We label these relations as SMFP, the abbreviation of, ΓÇÿSpin Modified Fundamental PlaneΓÇÖ. The SMFP relation can be expressed as Introducing the scalings LR, 38 = LR/1038erg ┬╖ sΓêÆ1, LX, 40 = LX/1040erg ┬╖ sΓêÆ1, and MBH, 8 = MBH/108MΓèÖ, one can express all the data in the form Superscript i is the label of each AGN. In standard Fundamental Plane relation, spin is set to a constant value and spin information is not included. ╬ö quantifies the scatter of each data point with respect to the FP predictions as the variance of all the data points is minimized. Hence, by definiton, ╬öFP = 0 for the standard FP relation Merloni et al. 2003; Falcke et al. 2004; Koerding et al. 2006. However, ╬ö changes between ΓêÆ3 to 2 for various data points. When BH spin is included, ╬ö becomes a function of the BH spin. In Fig. , we show that the data fits this new prediction better by studying the suppression of the scatter. In order to show that the inclusion of the spin information decreases considerably the amount of scatter, we invert the equation above and define the scatter function as In the SMFP, this function is predicted as We obtain , after minimizing the error variance. We also find that the AGNs nearly on the standard FP prediction corresponds to .3Fig. shows the data points for the 10 AGNs given in Table 1 as green dots. The blue dots and corresponding error bars are produced by employing the spin measurements and measurement errors in equation 18. It is clearly seen that in almost all cases, the spin modified expression tracks the data points better than the spin-blind standard prediction. ANALYSIS WITH BH SPIN IN THE FUNDAMENTAL PLANE We employ the data given in Table, and compute two quantities that signify the importance of the spin dependence. First, we use the face value of the independently measured spin(Brenneman et al. 2011) values and calculate standard deviation for ╬ö in both FP and Spin Modified FP SMFP. Second, we compute ╧ç2 error per degree of freedom, by taking into account the experimental error in spin measurements via using a top-hat probability distribution function for each spin value within a 1-╧â error range. In both cases, N = 10 for our analysis. where ΓÇÿ#ptsΓÇÖ indicate the number of sample points. As discussed in the previous section, ╬öth = 0 for FP , and for Spin Modified FP, it is given in equation. We obtain and . It should be noted that for AGNs with spin information, the variance is also consistent with the larger samples used in Refs Merloni et al. 2003; Koerding et al. 2006 Koerding et al. 2006;Merloni et al. 2003 .4 We suggest that the nonlinear effects of spin modification on the radiation efficiency and jet power is the main cause of this behaviour and our SMFP prediction shows a remarkable consistency with the data. Note that the selection of data might have a role at some degree and an analysis with higher precision spin and radiation data could allow us to test our predictions better. We calculate ╧ç2 parameter per degree of freedom as Here , and , and due to top hat distribution estimation. Nearly all measurements have mass, radio and X-ray measurements with an error of 0.2 in log base, so we set ╬öLR = ╬öLX = ╬öM = 0.2. We obtain and . Hence the inclusion of spin correction improves the fitting considerably .5 We define and plot in Fig. , this new spin modified variable, on the bottom panel and LR on the left panel as a function of . In both cases the slope of the line is 1. For the standard FP plane, there is considerable scatter shown in the top panel, but the scatter decreases considerably with this new variable. However, the prediction curve on the right panel is still not razor-thin. There are potentially some reasons for that including the thickness of the accretion disk enters as an independent variable, data uncertainties, LX ΓêÆ Ldisk and LR ΓêÆ Ljet connection, etc and they are discussed in more detail in the next subsections. Spin Dependence of the Fundamental Plane As discussed in the previous section, there exists a natural cutoff value for the spin value in the Blandford-ZnajekBZ process, . In the regime of low spins, winds and Blandford-Payne type processes dominate over BZ. This leads to a nearly constant and small outflow for small spins. However, we estimate that BZ quickly starts dominating the power outflow at moderate spin values and the jet power grows even more nonlinearly for large spins. At low spin values, the ISCO is nearly constant and the angular frequency grows quadratically. As the spin grows the location of the inner layers of the accretion disk equivalently the location of the source for the magnetic field gets closer to the horizon. As a result, the BZ output changes more dramatically with growing spin. Since the jet and radiation 6 efficiency have different functional dependence on the spin value, this results in strong scatter of the data from the standard FP relation when the spin information is not included , and . If one assumes only quadratic dependence to spin value, the jet power grows from to about a factor of 6, and interestingly, the radiation efficiency also grows by a factor of 62013 from small spin values to large spin values, This can be easily seen either from equation2 or approximately1 from the variation of the location of the ISCO in inverse gravitational potential, . Transfering these results to the FP variables, we get that the spin dependent contribution to the X-ray and radio power is modest. When we repeat our statistical analysis for the Ljet Γê¥ a2, we find only slight improvement in deviations, namely and . However, the stronger spin dependence of the jet power results in and . Residual Scatter Here we note some potential reasons about the residual scatter in SMFP: SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS2019 In accreting and outflowing BHs, the Fundamental Abramowicz et al. 1995; Akiyama et al. 2019; Almeida & Nemmen 2020Plane relation is 2015 one of the most important scalings relating three variables: the radio luminosity indicating jet power, X-ray luminosityindicating bolometric disk luminosity and the BH mass. Although standard FP equation gives a good description of (Blandford & Payne 1982)jet producing systems with sub-Eddington accretion rate, there are still considerable deviations around this relation. In order to explain these deviations, we investigated the spin dependence of the jet power and accretion power. We can summarize the effects of the BH spin on the jet and accretion power as follows: As the spin grows i a larger fraction of the gravitational energy can be released as radiation since the inner orbits of the accreting matter could come closer to the horizon, ii the magnetic field amplitude around the horizon grows since the source for the magnetic field comes closer, iii the angular frequency of the horizon grows, iv the size of the horizon decreases. We derived three main results: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS We would like to thank Ruth Daly, Kaz─▒m Yavuz Ek┼ƒi, Charles Gammie, Gabriele Ghisellini, Kianusch Mehrgan, Coleman Miller, Roberto Oliveri, Gizem ┼₧eng├╢r, Bayram Tekin and Federico Urban for discussions on a variety of topics; Tansu Daylan and St├⌐phane Ili─ç related with the statistical analysis; Ivan Almeida, Heino Falcke, Kayhan G├╝ltekin, Sebastian Heinz, Elmar K├╢rding, Sera Markoff, Richard Plotkin and Gustavo Soares for their comments on the manuscript. We also would like to thank anonymous referee for her/his comments. Footnotes We use disk luminosity and accretion power interchangeably throughout the text. Note that the other mechanisms freeing energy from the BH, such as Blandford-Payne and winds, exist but in numerous GRMHD simulations, BZ is the main outflow reason. Note that the spin distribution of heavy BHs are found to be moderate and large Volonteri et al. 2005 even if the disk is geometrically thick. Similar scatters were found in Ref. Merloni et al. 2003 , Ref. Gultekin et al. 2009 , and for LINERS Nisbet & Best 2016 . fnt.p: We use disk luminosity and accretion power interchangeably throughout the text.
Note that the other mechanisms freeing energy from the BH, such as Blandford-Payne and winds, exist but in numerous GRMHD simulations, BZ is the main outflow reason.
Note that the spin distribution of heavy BHs are found to be moderate and large (Volonteri et al. 2005) even if the disk is geometrically thick.
Similar scatters were found in Ref. (Merloni et al. 2003) (), Ref. (Gultekin et al. 2009) (), and for LINERS (Nisbet & Best 2016) ().

This result could also be strengthened by using a Bayesian approach such as one conducted in Ref. (Plotkin et al. 2012). Doppler beaming effects could be reason of slight outlying of AGN 3C 120. Lorentz factor of about 5 and small viewing angle could improve the even further.
